subject: Re: [junit] Re: Experience with jdk1.4 assert keyword
msgSnippet: Basically you are right... You could use both methods to target the same sort of issues. What should the software do when incorrect / inconsistent parameters
messageBody:
Basically
you are right...
You could use both methods to target the same sort of issues.
What should the software do when incorrect / inconsistent parameters
are introduced ?
Now, Vladimir's reamrk is also quiet relevant as you will probabaly dissable
the Assertion mechanism in your production environment ! I would also take
the safe path to keep the Exception in my code. Remember also that there i
sno proof that no idiot put in his code smthg like
Assert x < y++ ;

Exception mechanism is therefore a must have in any decent production
environment, as of today.
Anyone can envisage that the assertion mechanism may be smart enough one
day to not slow down the
program ... hence being run everytime !

Thomas,



http://java.sun.com/j2se/1.4/docs/guide/lang/assert.html

----- Original Message -----
From: "rasmus4200" <jr@...>
To: <junit@yahoogroups.com>
Sent: Thursday, January 17, 2002 12:33 AM
Subject: [junit] Re: Experience with jdk1.4 assert keyword


> --- In junit@y..., Mark Meyers <markm@m...> wrote:
> > >But they are a great way to
> > >communicate your intentions (example: asserting that the integer
> parameter
> > >of a method is greater than 0 communicates to the reader of the
> code your
> > >assumptions about the way that the method should be used). IMHO,
> that's the
> > >most important reason to use asserts.
> >
> > Are you saying you prefer to use the assert or the
> IllegalArgumentException
> > in this case ?
> > In the example I would prefer the Exception, to enforce my
> preconditions.
> > Asserts allow the method to be executed with a negative parameter,
> maybe
> > resulting in some fictitious value being returned without
> detection.
> >
> > I see more relevance in asserting assumptions being made about the
> internal
> > state of an object, (but then you are probably not writing unit
> tests, if
> > you need to do that...).
> >
> > Using JUnit, I do not yet see the usefulness/necessity of the assert
> > statement. Maybe I'm just missing something ?
>
> No I do not think you are missing anything. This is what prompted me
> to ask this question in the first place. When would one use an
> exception vs an 'assert'.
>
> if (n<0)
> throw new IllegalArgumentException();
>
> and
>
> assert n < 0
>
> are to me the same thing. The differences are the following:
>
> the assert:
> - is more elegant
> - is more useful at development time (as an AssertionError is
> generated versus an exception)
> - is more severe then the exception (since its an error)
> - can not be ignored (exception can be ignored via emtpy try catch
> block)
> - may lead to clear code (I cant prove this yet.. just a hunch)
>
> the exception:
> - is more standard
> - is more explicit (IllegalArgument tells me the exact problem)
> - better communicated in docs (javadoc picks it up, hopefully this
> will change for assertions one day)
>
> But at the end of the day they the look the same to me - just
> different in implementation.
>
> Jonathan
